channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Julian Assange Duty Is Draining Police Coffers, London Chief Says
item.description: London’s police chief said Tuesday that the cost of keeping watch on Mr. Assange, who is holed up in the Ecuadorean Embassy there, was draining resources and must be reviewed.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Clinic to Pay in Baby Swap
item.description: A French court on Tuesday ordered a private clinic in Cannes to pay about $450,000 each to two 20-year-old women accidentally switched at birth, part of a $2.1 million settlement with both their families.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Putin Announces Plan to Help Build Nuclear Power Plant
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his Egyptian counterpart, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, said Tuesday in Cairo that the two countries planned to jointly build Egypt’s first nuclear power plant.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama to Seek War Power Bill From Congress, to Fight ISIS
item.description: The Obama administration has informed lawmakers that the president will seek an authorization that would prohibit “enduring offensive ground forces” and limit engagement to three years.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY W. PETERS
item.media:description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, said he was skeptical about the request.

item.title: Kayla Mueller’s Parents Receive Photos of Her Body From ISIS
item.description: Islamic State, which had held Kayla Mueller captive since August 2013, sent her parents least three photographs of her corpse as proof of death.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Kayla Mueller, with her dog, wrote about her captivity in a letter her family made public Tuesday.

item.title: Towers of Secrecy: Mexican Political Family Has Close PRI Ties, and Homes in the U.S.
item.description: The properties stand in contrast to the working-man image promoted by José Murat Casab, a longtime party insider, and his son, a top housing official.
item.dc:creator: By LOUISE STORY and ALEJANDRA XANIC von BERTRAB
item.media:description: José Murat Casab, left, a former governor of Oaxaca and an influential member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party. Members of his immediate family have bought at least six properties in the United States, records and interviews show.

item.title: Jordan and Emirates Carry Out Airstrikes in Syria Against ISIS
item.description: The United Arab Emirates returned to combat missions against the Islamic State for the first time since December, and Jordan separately continued its escalation of strikes against Sunni militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Australia Holds 2 in Terrorism Case
item.description: Police officers arrested two men in a Sydney suburb and thwarted an “imminent” terrorist attack, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Bangkok Journal: In Thailand, the Ghost Business Thrives
item.description: Kapol Thongplub, who hosts a nightly call-in show in Thailand dedicated to the supernatural, has become the leading ghost expert in a country that takes them quite seriously.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Guilio Di Sturco for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kapol Thongplub has been listening to ghost stories for two decades as host of “The Shock.”

item.title: Open Source: On YouTube, Vivid Evidence of War’s Horror in Ukraine
item.description: The war in Ukraine can be viewed, in all its horror and brutality, by anyone with an Internet connection.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Terrorist Claims Return Sept. 11 Suit to Spotlight
item.description: In 2002, victims’ families sued the government of Saudi Arabia and the Saudi elite, including banks, charities and even members of the royal family, accusing them of financing Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN

item.title: Obama to Recall Military Personnel From Ebola Zone, Officials Say
item.description: The president will also outline new steps aimed at eradicating the disease now that the crisis in West Africa has eased, the officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Air Force personnel in Liberia in October. All but 100 of the 3,000 armed forces members deployed to fight Ebola in West Africa will return home by the end of April, officials said.

item.title: Agreement on Ukraine Cease-Fire Deal Is Reported
item.description: Negotiators meeting in Belarus were said to have reached a tentative deal on Tuesday night, according to news reports.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: The former Ukrainian president Leonid M. Kuchma, left, and the Russian ambassador to Ukraine, Mikhail Y. Zurabov, are in Minsk, Belarus, along with other leaders to arrange a cease-fire in Ukraine.

item.title: Venezuela Announces Plan to Relax Currency Controls
item.description: The move is an easing of the system of tightly controlled exchange rates that critics say have fed the nation’s economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: India’s Aam Aadmi Party Sweeps Elections in Delhi
item.description: The party of the anticorruption campaigner Arvind Kejriwal won 67 of the 70 seats in the Delhi Assembly, on promises of helping the poor.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Supporters of the Aam Aadmi Party, or Common Man Party, celebrated in New Delhi on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing: New DNA Tests Ordered in Argentine Prosecutor’s Death
item.description: A judge in Argentina wants to know the identity of new traces of DNA found at the home of the prosecutor, Alberto Nisman.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Robert Herzstein, 74, Dies; Historian Linked a U.N. Leader to War Crimes
item.description: Mr. Herzstein’s prodigious archival research on behalf of the World Jewish Congress helped uncover Kurt Waldheim’s veiled ties to Nazi war crimes.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SAM ROBERTS
item.media:credit: Marilyn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Herzstein, center, presenting documents linking Kurt Waldheim to Nazi war crimes in 1986.

item.title: Niger Adds Its Troops to the War on Boko Haram
item.description: The National Assembly’s vote to join the fight was unanimous, and followed several attacks in Niger in less than a week.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Yemeni Militant Leader Pledges to Share Power
item.description: Saleh Ali al-Sammad, a senior Houthi leader, said the group wanted to share power with its political rivals and maintain good relations with the United States and Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and SHUAIB ALMOSAWA
item.media:description: Saleh Ali al-Sammad, the senior Houthi official in Sana, is viewed as second in political importance to the Houthis’ top leader, Abdul-Malik al-Houthi.

item.title: Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s Defense: He Didn’t Know Prostitutes Were at the Orgies
item.description: The former I.M.F. chief, who acknowledges a libertine lifestyle, stands accused with 13 others of pimping and of aiding and abetting the prostitution of seven women.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Topless protesters were detained Tuesday after they threw themselves at a car carrying Dominique Strauss-Kahn in Lille, France.
